citation.article-title: Erythrobacter vulgaris sp. nov., a novel organism isolated from the marine invertebrates.

p.s: Description of Erythrobacter vulgaris sp. nov.
Erythrobacter vulgaris (vul’ga.ris L. masc. adj. vulgaris, ordinary, usual, common).
Cells are 0.6–0.8 μm in diameter and 1.2–1.8 μm long.
Chemoorganotrophs.
Nonmotile.
Aerobic and Gram-negative.
Oxidase- and catalase-positive.
Growth occurs between 10 and 40 °C with optimum at 28–30 °C.
No growth is detected at 4 °C and at 45 °C.
The pH for growth ranges from 6.0 to 10.0, with optimum at 7.5–8.5.
Growth occurred at 1–3% of NaCl, some strains are tolerated to 6–8% NaCl.
Hydrolyze Tween 80, some strains weakly hydrolyze starch.
Gelatin, casein and DNA are not hydrolyzed.
Do not produce indole, acetoin, and H2S.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
Do not utilize α-d-glucose, sucrose, α-d-lactose, maltose, d-ribose, arabinose, melibiose, l-rhamnose, xylose, citrate, mannitol, and galactose.
Some strains weakly utilize sorbose, inositol, and adonitol, susceptible to oleandomycin.
Non-susceptible to kanamycin, tetracyclin, neomycin, streptomycin, gentamicin, polymyxin, benzylpenicillin, and lincomycin.
PE, PG and PC are the predominant phospholipids.
The major cellular fatty acids are 16:0, 16:1ω7, and 18:1ω7.
The two-hydroxy fatty acids, 13:0-2OH, 14:0-2OH, 15:0-2OH, 16:0-2OH are also present.
Isolated from starfish Stellaster equestris and soft coral (unidentified species) collected in the South China Sea.
The G+C content of the DNA is 60.5 mol%.
Type strain is 022-2-10T (=KMM 3465T=CIP 107841T).
